executive_summary: Mexico's NOM-035 workplace psychosocial risk regulation expanded to cover remote/hybrid work, added digital disconnection rights, lowered evaluation threshold from 50 to 15 employees, doubled evaluation frequency to semi-annual, introduced mandatory clinical assessment for high-risk sectors, and doubled penalties.

what_changed.change: Employee threshold for mandatory psychosocial risk evaluation lowered from 50 to 15 workers (Artículo 5)
Evaluation frequency increased from annual to semi-annual (Artículo 7)
New digital disconnection right (derecho a la desconexión digital) — employers must guarantee workers' right to disconnect outside working hours
Scope expanded to cover remote work, hybrid arrangements, and digital platform workers (Artículo 2)
New Article 7-Bis: Mandatory annual clinical evaluation by certified mental health professionals for high-risk sectors (health, security, emergency, education, high-volume customer service)
Penalties approximately doubled across all categories; two new penalty categories added for digital disconnection violations and missing clinical evaluations
New digital risk assessment module required for workplaces with >30% remote staff (Artículo 5.III)

deadlines.item: 90 days after DOF publication: New regulation enters into force (Transitorio Primero)
180 days: Existing workplaces must comply with digital disconnection and semi-annual evaluation requirements (Transitorio Segundo)
270 days: High-risk sector employers must implement clinical evaluation per Article 7-Bis (Transitorio Tercero)
deadlines.owner: Health, security, emergency, education, customer service employers

deadlines.item: 60 days after entry: STPS to publish guidelines for digital risk assessment module (Transitorio Cuarto)
deadlines.owner: Secretaría del Trabajo y Previsión Social (STPS)

action_checklist.action: Assess current employee count against new 15-worker threshold for mandatory psychosocial risk evaluation
Implement digital disconnection policy establishing clear availability hours for all employees
Update evaluation schedule from annual to semi-annual and budget accordingly
Determine if organization falls under high-risk sector definition requiring clinical evaluation (Article 7-Bis)
Establish digital reporting channels for psychosocial risk complaints per updated Article 6.I
Conduct ergonomic assessment of remote work spaces if company provides or mandates remote work

risk_flags.why: Lowering the threshold from 50 to 15 employees brings thousands of small businesses into mandatory evaluation scope, many lacking existing psychosocial risk programs.
All penalty ranges approximately doubled, with maximum fines reaching 1000 UMA per worker for unaddressed risks. New penalty categories add further exposure.
Inclusion of 'digital platform workers' and 'virtual workplaces' may create classification disputes about which workers and arrangements fall under the regulation.
Requirement for certified mental health professionals in high-risk sectors may face supply constraints given the 270-day implementation timeline.
